unnormalised: **Automotive News: Fuel Efficiency Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **Automotive News: Fuel Efficiency Gains Momentum in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26th - As fuel prices continue to pinch pockets, automotive manufacturers in India are doubling down on fuel efficiency innovations. Dr. Meena Sharma, lead researcher at IIT Madras' Automotive Research Center, highlighted the recent advancements. "We're seeing significant improvements thanks to lighter materials, optimized engine designs and enhanced aerodynamics."
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty sixth - As fuel prices continue to pinch pockets, automotive manufacturers in India are doubling down on fuel efficiency innovations. Doctor Meena Sharma, lead researcher at I I T Madras' Automotive Research Center, highlighted the recent advancements. "We're seeing significant improvements thanks to lighter materials, optimized engine designs and enhanced aerodynamics."

unnormalised: The latest Bharat Stage VI emission standards have also played a crucial role. Maruti Suzuki recently unveiled a new CNG variant boasting a mileage of 35 km/kg, a considerable jump from earlier models. Furthermore, initiatives like the FAME India scheme are incentivizing electric vehicle adoption.
normalised: The latest Bharat Stage six emission standards have also played a crucial role. Maruti Suzuki recently unveiled a new C N G variant boasting a mileage of thirty five kilometer per kilogram, a considerable jump from earlier models. Furthermore, initiatives like the F A M E India scheme are incentivizing electric vehicle adoption.

unnormalised: "Even slight improvements, say 2-3 kmpl, can translate to substantial savings for the average Indian household, especially for families in cities like Mumbai navigating daily commutes," stated auto analyst, Rajesh Khanna. With growing consumer awareness and government support, the future of fuel-efficient vehicles looks promising in the Indian market, covering vast geographical areas, even properties spanning hundreds of sq ft. The reduction in fuel consumption will also lead to a dip in Rs spent by the average car owner.
normalised: "Even slight improvements, say two to three kilometer per liter, can translate to substantial savings for the average Indian household, especially for families in cities like Mumbai navigating daily commutes," stated auto analyst, Rajesh Khanna. With growing consumer awareness and government support, the future of fuel-efficient vehicles looks promising in the Indian market, covering vast geographical areas, even properties spanning hundreds of square feet. The reduction in fuel consumption will also lead to a dip in rupees spent by the average car owner.
